turn.text: And therefore why is this a final order, and if it is not as you know we do not have any jurisdiction over it?

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: It is a question that I have not considered previously Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it just occurred to me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you need counsel?

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: Pardon.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you need counsel?

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: Yeah, I will take it if I can get it.
I want to correct…

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is it your position that you are entitled to have this issues resolved at the outset, that it is a due process, that you have directed to due process to have this issue resolved?

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, the property of these defendants has been tied up for two-and-a-half years.

No responsible official of the state of Delaware has ever during that period considered whether there is a baseless or a sound or any other kind of claim against them to justify that deprivation of their property.
We think that it is more than long enough for that condition to be allowed to continue and that it is time for it to be ended.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you suggest there is no mandamus remedy available to you, if you bring that to a head?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then there will be no more claim.

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: We have pursued the matter through the state court system to the end point.
Delaware Supreme Court has rendered its final judgment on the matter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Though on this basically interlocutory matter.

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: To the extent a two-and-a-half-year deprivation is interlocutory.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Under the Delaware judgment, all that needs, all it has decided is that you are properly in the lawsuit, a lawsuit now can go on, on the merits, that’s all the Delaware has been told.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Doesn’t the judgment hold that your property has been seized and if you don’t submit to that jurisdiction, your property is gone?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Certainly, Mr. Justice Marshal.
That is what that they tend to --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Was that interlocutory?

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: I am sorry.
I missed your question Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If you do not submit to that jurisdiction, which you say they do not have, then you lose your property, that’s been decided.

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: That’s clear.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That’s good.

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: The only step remaining is to conduct the final hearing and the sale of the property.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, only that is if you are going to default in the lawsuit?

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, let us say this were a case in Delaware in which there was a personal service upon a resident defendant of Delaware and his claim was there was something defective about that service and that as a constitutional matter there was something defective of the personal service of him and Delaware.
He brought that up all the way up to the Delaware Supreme Court and Delaware Supreme Court said no as a constitutional matter that is end as well as statutory, this is a perfectly valid service.
Then this court would not have jurisdiction that way, not the interlocutory.
All I would have decided was that you and Mr. Defendant have to go and defend the lawsuit.

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: In this case Delaware Supreme Court has issue a final judgment as to the validity of the taking of the defendant’s property.
The defense now has only the choice that you pointed out.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Defaulting in lawsuit or defending it?

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: Or to enter a general appearance and giving up at that point, their rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, having a trial in a proper form.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, but because you might win on the merits, and if you loose on the merits you would not have given up your Fourteenth Amendment plan, because it then would be a final judgment that you could bring to this court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I understood your position the way that you loose your constitutional right to have the case tried in a proper forum, and the Delaware is not the proper forum, is that your position?

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: That is our position Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And you are saying that this Thompson's (ph) choice is one that the provisions of due process should guarantee that you should not have to make.

turn.speaker: john_r_reese
turn.label: Mr. John R. Reese
turn.text: Yes, the defendants stand a loose a lot by just being forced to the trial on the merits at this point, part of the point of it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that’s one of the prices of not allowing the interlocutory appeals too.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen the case is submitted.
